intro: Centaurea corensis, commonly known as the Cornflower, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that consist of both ray and disk flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with slender stems and lance-shaped leaves. Its bright blue to purple flowers bloom from late spring to early autumn, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Centaurea corensis is often found in meadows, grasslands, and along roadsides, and it has been cultivated for its ornamental value and historical use in herbal medicine.
